title: Tevo Black Widow Fan Duct without BL Touch Mount

description.text:
I was looking for a solution to the fan hanging in free air for my Black Widow and liked the look of thing:1963986 however I did not want the BL Touch mount as I had already printed the LPA fan duct (with the BL Touch mount.) I have 'almost' removed the BLT mount, however there is a small amount of it left on the side of the duct, but not enough to worry me to go in an remove it completely. (It is well hidden behind the fan.)

Very happy with the result and I hope that others can use as is or further modify to suit.

description.text:
Ever wonder who took the cookie from the cookie jar? I certainly do, so I decided to make a RC Spy Rover! The rover uses a 3d printed pan tilt fpv system in order to spy on an area and can move from place to place by using two modified 360 servos to drive around. Building this project is as simple as it gets (Just plugging wires into a receiver) so its a great project for kids or beginners!

Instructable: https://www.instructables.com/id/How-to-Make-a-Remote-Controlled-Spy-Rover/
Youtube Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wlqGBkWdxTs

You will need to print
2x Wheel

Notes:

Printed in TPU

• When removing support material from the side lobes, needle nose pliers are required.
  • My prints had heavy stringing. I cut off as much as I could with scissors and burned off the rest with a lighter.
  • My prints delaminated at the thinnest points under the side lobes. To fix this, I tried gluing one with epoxy, and on the other I melted the layers back together with the tip of a 3D pen. Both techniques worked.

Some restrictions may apply, blah blah blah...

description.text:
This is for good display and fun. The design is similar to my Z-12A. The only difference is the Z-12B has a delta wing other than a swipe wing. If you like this model you should check out my Z-12A. Hope you will enjoy. Please file or sand off the sharp edges, before handing it to any children as a toy.

If your slicer have an option to use only "exterior support", then use it, because this could save you a lot of time and work. Using exterior support only means there will be no support structure in between the model. Therefore you will only have to clean up the supports that hold the wing and fuselage.

author: morris_lan

description.text: A puppy's head... just a little dog's head

It's a case for a Raspberry Pi radio transmitter. Has enough room for a Pi, USB battery case, and lengthy cable. Learn more at http://makezine.com/projects/raspberry-pirate-radio/ Print in two pieces and snap together.

I always checkout bargain bins for what else, bargains!! I found a flambeau tackle box with a missing handle deeply discounted. Not a problem for a 3d printer. a few measurements, a couple test pieces and a new handle was ready. Printed in Hatchbox brown, looks like it belongs on it.

Printer:

Hictop 3dp-17

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

20%
remove the support material, round over the edges, about all it needs.

i measured the slot that the factory handle would fit in, not easy as it was recessed. I printed 3 sizes of pins to check both the insertion force to seat the handle and for best fit as the molding in the handle area had small protrusions to help retain the handle. A hollow spot was built into the backside of the handle to accommodate this feature. For the Flambeau T4 Multiloader, a 11mm pin fit perfect. I opted for a fuller width handle rather then the narrower factory handle.

Tilted containers, with a built in lid. This was designed to more efficiently use the build volume of the printer than other integrated lid cases I've designed and still print without support.

There are several sizes and divider configurations, as I print more variations, I'll add them to this thing. Probably best to print in PETG because of the living hinge.

Atomic Filament PETG in Emerald Green, Sapphire Blue and Ruby Red. 3D Solutech Transparent Blue PETG* (the lighter shade of blue), Sainsmart Clear PETG*.

This was designed in Onshape, and you can modify the document to create your own case. Changing the main dimension variables (width, length, and depth) should work work, but modifying the dividers or the tilt angle will probably require more manual editing.

title: Gas Strut End, Ball joint Cup 10mm, M6x1

description.text:
This is a ball joint cup end for gas struts. It suits a 10mm ball, and an M6x1 connecting thread. The thread is modelled and can be used directly after printing.

Note the retainer wire clip is extended down to touch the print bed for a clean print. Just cut through it in a position where you get a slight overlap with the retaining wire to keep it captive. Retainer wire holes are sized to 1.1mm dia.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Print cup face down. Tested with ABS. May also work with PETG and nylon. Grease ball joint before installing.

Important: I printed these wiht Skin expansion of 0.85mm. If this is not set the ball joint may be slightly loose.

I used a hair pin cut to size for the retainign clip (in the photos). This seems to work well.

title: Kegbot case for mainboard and coaster

description.text: 2 piece cases for both the coaster and the mainboard.  Coaster has cutouts for the flowmeter, ethernet jack and a screwhole mount.  Mainboard has cutouts for both coaster jacks, usb and power.  Also has markings for port # and rfid location
I printed this in PLA with standard 10% infill.  There are overhangs so a fan is recommended.  Rotate coaster with tall part vertical.  Print mainboard case upside down.

title: Lockheed SR-71A Blackbird
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Support me on Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/oranhunter

This is the Blackbird. This is the most beautiful aircraft ever created. This represents about 20 hours of modeling and detailing, just for you. This is the best I could do for now. I'm only about 2 years into modeling, and this represents where I'm at with my modeling ability.

UPDATE: I added an unsliced version as well. Be advised it doesn't have the hole to accept the stand in the bottom of it. It's just a clean model.

UPDATE 2/19/2018: I realized the cockpit doors weren't properly mirrored. They're hardly visible on the right side in the old V2 cockpit. I uploaded V3 just now and it is properly mirrored!

comments.text: I only have 1 problem with the model the cones on the air intake appear to be angled down. now correct me if I am wrong but don't they spin with the jet turbines? kinda hard to do when the axis of rotation is not the axis of symmetry. this is just me being nitpicky so please don't take this as me saying it is a bad model, it is a great model. just some constructive criticism. and do you think you could make an SR-72 model?
comments.author: TFMCDerek

comments.text: Never mind looking at some pictures they do point down a little
comments.author: TFMCDerek

comments.text: Haha, I'm glad you found the answer. The answer is they don't spin. They would extend out or retract based on airspeed. Their sole purpose was to make sure that the airflow through the engine wouldn't 'blow out' the combustion when breaking the sound barrier(which creates shock waves that need to be controlled at higher mach speeds).

comments.text: There were a lot of things we couldn’t do in an SR-71, but we were the fastest guys on the block and loved reminding our fellow aviators of this fact. People often asked us if, because of this fact, it was fun to fly the jet. Fun would not be the first word I would use to describe flying this plane. Intense, maybe. Even cerebral. But there was one day in our Sled experience when we would have to say that it was pure fun to be the fastest guys out there, at least for a moment. It occurred when Walt and I were flying our final training sortie. We needed 100 hours in the jet to complete our training and attain Mission Ready status. Somewhere over Colorado we had passed the century mark. We had made the turn in Arizona and the jet was performing flawlessly. My gauges were wired in the front seat and we were starting to feel pretty good about ourselves, not only because we would soon be flying real missions but because we had gained a great deal of confidence in the plane in the past ten months. Ripping across the barren deserts 80,000 feet below us, I could already see the coast of California from the Arizona border. I was, finally, after many humbling months of simulators and study, ahead of the jet. I was beginning to feel a bit sorry for Walter in the back seat. There he was, with no really good view of the incredible sights before us, tasked with monitoring four different radios. This was good practice for him for when we began flying real missions, when a priority transmission from headquarters could be vital. It had been difficult, too, for me to relinquish control of the radios, as during my entire flying career I had controlled my own transmissions. But it was part of the division of duties in this plane and I had adjusted to it. I still insisted on talking on the radio while we were on the ground, however. Walt was so good at many things, but he couldn’t match my expertise at sounding smooth on the radios, a skill that had been honed sharply with years in fighter squadrons where the slightest radio miscue was grounds for beheading. He understood that and allowed me that luxury. Just to get a sense of what Walt had to contend with, I pulled the radio toggle switches and monitored the frequencies along with him. The predominant radio chatter was from Los Angeles Center, far below us, controlling daily traffic in their sector. While they had us on their scope (albeit briefly), we were in uncontrolled airspace and normally would not talk to them unless we needed to descend into their airspace. We listened as the shaky voice of a lone Cessna pilot asked Center for a readout of his ground speed. Center replied: “November Charlie 175, I’m showing you at ninety knots on the ground.” Now the thing to understand about Center controllers, was that whether they were talking to a rookie pilot in a Cessna, or to Air Force One, they always spoke in the exact same, calm, deep, professional, tone that made one feel important. I referred to it as the ” Houston Center voice.” I have always felt that after years of seeing documentaries on this country’s space program and listening to the calm and distinct voice of the Houston controllers, that all other controllers since then wanted to sound like that, and that they basically did. And it didn’t matter what sector of the country we would be flying in, it always seemed like the same guy was talking. Over the years that tone of voice had become somewhat of a comforting sound to pilots everywhere. Conversely, over the years, pilots always wanted to ensure that, when transmitting, they sounded like Chuck Yeager, or at least like John Wayne. Better to die than sound bad on the radios. Just moments after the Cessna’s inquiry, a Twin Beech piped up on frequency, in a rather superior tone, asking for his ground speed. “I have you at one hundred and twenty-five knots of ground speed.” Boy, I thought, the Beechcraft really must think he is dazzling his Cessna brethren. Then out of the blue, a navy F-18 pilot out of NAS Lemoore came up on frequency. You knew right away it was a Navy jock because he sounded very cool on the radios. “Center, Dusty 52 ground speed check”. Before Center could reply, I’m thinking to myself, hey, Dusty 52 has a ground speed indicator in that million-dollar cockpit, so why is he asking Center for a readout? Then I got it, ol’ Dusty here is making sure that every bug smasher from Mount Whitney to the Mojave knows what true speed is. He’s the fastest dude in the valley today, and he just wants everyone to know how much fun he is having in his new Hornet. And the reply, always with that same, calm, voice, with more distinct alliteration than emotion: “Dusty 52, Center, we have you at 620 on the ground.” And I thought to myself, is this a ripe situation, or what? As my hand instinctively reached for the mic button, I had to remind myself that Walt was in control of the radios. Still, I thought, it must be done – in mere seconds we’ll be out of the sector and the opportunity will be lost. That Hornet must die, and die now. I thought about all of our Sim training and how important it was that we developed well as a crew and knew that to jump in on the radios now would destroy the integrity of all that we had worked toward becoming. I was torn. Somewhere, 13 miles above Arizona, there was a pilot screaming inside his space helmet. Then, I heard it. The click of the mic button from the back seat. That was the very moment that I knew Walter and I had become a crew. Very professionally, and with no emotion, Walter spoke: “Los Angeles Center, Aspen 20, can you give us a ground speed check?” There was no hesitation, and the replay came as if was an everyday request. “Aspen 20, I show you at one thousand eight hundred and forty-two knots, across the ground.” I think it was the forty-two knots that I liked the best, so accurate and proud was Center to deliver that information without hesitation, and you just knew he was smiling. But the precise point at which I knew that Walt and I were going to be really good friends for a long time was when he keyed the mic once again to say, in his most fighter-pilot-like voice: “Ah, Center, much thanks, we’re showing closer to nineteen hundred on the money.” For a moment Walter was a god. And we finally heard a little crack in the armor of the Houston Center voice, when L.A.came back with, “Roger that Aspen, Your equipment is probably more accurate than ours. You boys have a good one.” It all had lasted for just moments, but in that short, memorable sprint across the southwest, the Navy had been flamed, all mortal airplanes on freq were forced to bow before the King of Speed, and more importantly, Walter and I had crossed the threshold of being a crew. A fine day’s work. We never heard another transmission on that frequency all the way to the coast.

description.text:
Update 7/4/2017: I'm opening up the file to V2, which is pictured above after the shots of V1. I haven't uploaded the .STL files yet, but anyone who wants to can grab from the Tinkercad project itself, here:
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/6RZwES0neNK-bubbles-v2/
V2 is a wee bit (!) more powerful, with a 1:125 gear ratio instead of 1:9, a larger and much optimized impeller, and a larger inflow tract. I don't have time to make assembly instructions right now, but you can figure it out from the Tinkercad project. Some advice: assemble the base first, then the middle wall and its attachments.

(Now, back to the original text)

Just in time for Summer (Northern Hemisphere, I know).

Print 1 of each part (you can add several of the gears together into 1 print). Some will need to be rotated to lay flat on your bed. No supports are needed. Prints well at .25mm/layer with 3 shells. For most parts, 20% infill is adequate. For the middle wall I recommend 50% or higher, to support the torque on those rather thin pegs.

Pay close attention to the assembly schematics above. On Drive gear A, you want to tighten the two nuts together, NOT tighten either nut to the bolt head.

Fill the reservoir with bubble fluid (water, dish soap, and glycerin) just enough to cover the bubble rings (too much and it will make a slippery mess). Crank the handle and enjoy the bubbles. Right now it mostly makes a single mass of bubbles dangling off the back side, so it clearly needs tinkering. Maybe shaping the impeller case outflow tract into a round tube, right up next to the bubble wheel? Maybe larger impeller blades? Maybe reverse the direction of the bubble wheel's rotation? If you want to tinker with it and make it better, here's the link: https://tinkercad.com/things/jGSvj2vejI9

Impeller playground of untested ideas:
https://tinkercad.com/things/j6eoRn6QKR6

Impeller design is its own field of hydraulic engineering, and clearly has a massive impact on fan output. If interested, check out these discussions here:

  • https://www.ekwestrel.com/is-there-an-ideal-impeller-vane-number/
  • http://www.enginsoft.it/applications/turbomacchine/sulzer.html
    When I get a chance to model some more, I plan to try a helical blade impeller such as this:
  • https://www.caeses.com/forum/uploads/monthly_05_2013/post-8-0-93091100-1368785425.png

For anyone wanting a simple hand-cranked impeller fan (also known as centrifugal fan), print everything except the Reservoir.stl, Bubble wheel.stl, Gear strap.stl, and Wheel pin.stl. The transmission results in a ~1:9 ratio of input to output.

Requires:

  • 8 shielded ball bearings, 608 size (22mm OD, 8mm ID, 7mm depth)
  • 2 hex bolts, 5/16", 2 inch length (sorry, don't know if there is a metric equivalent bolt)
  • Lots of M3 machine screws, 10mm and 20mm length
  • Several washers meant for 5/16" bolts, roughly 1.5mm thick

This project would not have been possible without the excellent gear generating project here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1604369

title: Micromake Flsun Kossel Mini Delta Printer Bed Mount

description.text:
First off, let me please ask that if you like these designs and find them useful please do like, follow and share my content. And if you have any ideas or concepts to modify the content I would love to hear!

This is a simple method to mounting the bed on a Kossel Mini Delta Printer. I use these feet (three per printer) on my Kossel Mini Delta Printers. The feet mount to the 2020 aluminium extrusion using the 4mm socket head cap screw bolts and captive style nuts. The Flsun Micromake series of delta 3D printers use 200mm glass beds and these feet allow for the irregular circular cut of the glass bed that the manufacturers have made to be used an advantage. The feet, when solidly mounted to the printer base bind when the glass bed is positioned on the printer. Place the glass bed on the loosely mounted bed feet, adjust them to press hard against the glass bed and tighten them down. Now when you place the glass bed in the printer and rotate the glass the feet lock the bed securely in place due to the irregular cut of the glass. Of course these also work well with other ~200mm diameter beds.

These lend themselves well to modifying to incorporate a latching type hold down system. So please do remake them and share your efforts. For me, they have been working flawlessly as is for over two years.

print_settings.Notes:: This item printed very well. A previous attempt was made at a layer height of .2, but it resulted in the hex nut holes being droopy and unable to accommodate the nuts. The mounting points for the bottom drive are on the bottom of the adapter and are conveniently out of the way of the 3.5" bay mounting holes. The design is relatively bendy if no drive is mounted, I would suggest mounting the 2.5" drive on the bottom if only one is being mounted.

description.text: This is a 3.5" drive to 2x 2.5" drive bay adapter. Printed in PLA, with 20% infill, weighs only 36 grams. This model can accommodate both 7mm and 9mm drives (7mm pictured). The mounting screws and hex nuts are standard M3, but any screw should be fine as long as the mounting hex nut has an outer diameter of 6mm or slightly less. While the mounting screw and nut are M3, it is important to note that 2.5" drives utilize M3 screws for mounting. The screws and nuts I used were "https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00032Q1J4/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1" and "https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000NBIH92/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1" respectively. Anything with similar dimensions would work just as well. I am in no way trying to promote or advertise these products, but they are the only ones I can guarantee work.

description.text: Shower curtain hook that fits over a shower stall upper glide bracket; can be used by a person who needs a bathtub/shower chair where the chair is too wide for the stall panels or the stall panels interfere with getting into or out of the chair.  (Also makes a nice accessory for a pirate costume.)

• Download STL file.

  • Scale file to fit around upper bracket for panels -- default is 1 7/8 x 2 inch (49 x 50mm) bracket..

  • Print or cut as many copies as there are holes along shower curtain -- usually 12 for 72 inch (6 foot or 1.8288m).

  • Fit bracket through gap in large ring and curtain through gap in small ring.

  • Repeat until entire curtain is supported (alternating the side of the bracket the hook is inserted on will reduce the chance of pulling the entire curtain down -- as in "Psycho").

description.text:
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1879518

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=1879518

Using the following options:

outsideBearingRadius = 10
legLength = 30
bearingHeight = 8
insideBearingRadius = 28
hThick = 2
hPlay = 0.1
roundness = 1.5
curveScale = 1.5
numberOfLegs = 0
curveOffset = 0
vPlay = 0
curveSizeAdjust = 0

When mounting spools on the back of the printer I often had trouble with the loop of filament going to the print head getting trapped underneath another loop. Since changing to this design I haven't experienced that problem. For each spool you will need a holder, a mirror image of the holder, two tubes, two spool bushes and two threaded bushes. The spool bushes are intentionally a loose fit on the metal tube, this puts the centre of gravity of the spool below the axis of the tube. The result of this is that when the print head moves away from the holder it raises the c of g of the spool creating tension so that when the head moves back towards the head the slack in the filament is taken up. The spool bush is designed for filament spools with a 58mm diameter hole but I've included the OpenScad file for this part so you can customize it to suit other spool sizes.
When I first posted this design I forgot to mention that I was using filament guide https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:616895 with a short length of 2mm inside diameter PTFE tube (see photo), I didn't realise that the slack in the filament only gets taken up when this is used.

As well as the printed parts for each spool you will need 300mm of 19mm diameter chrome-plated metal tube. This is available from hardware store, it's used for making clothes- and towel rails. To fit he holder to the machine place it in the corner of the top plate and using the holes in the holder as pilots drill three 3.2mm holes through the top plate taking care not to damage the mechanism below then secure with three M3 screws and nuts.

title: Shapeoko2 Modified Y limit / home switch

description.text: This is an adaptation of iquizzle's great limit switch mount that he made (I love the captive nut design!). You can find his original here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:215514 In my case, I wanted to switch around the switches and place them on the moving gantry rather than on the outside. So, in this configuration, it made more sense to use his Y limit switches on my X axis. So, I've left the title as Y limit since that is what I modified, but I am in fact using them for my X axis. I modified the hole spacing so they would mount nicely on the ends of the X axis in the space remaining when the makerslide is slid to one side (as it usually is). See pictures. To attach the switches, since space is tight, I found that #6 5/8" screws work great (as pictured). Sketchup and STL file are provided.
Printed on a makerbot replicator 2.  Attached switches using #6 5/8" screws.

description.text:
I was looking for a way to mount mechanical switches on the Z axis of my Shapeoko 2 and realized it might be nice to have a generic mount that could be mounted using a t-nut on any makerslide - z axis or otherwise.  
This is that attempt.  I should say I'm not entirely thrilled with this design, but I thought I would upload it in case it helps someone else.  One change I think I might make if I do move forward with switches like this is some sort of tab going down from the switch mount into the makerslide itself to lock the mount in place and not allow it to twist.  
I used a m3 12mm bolt to attach this to the makerslide via a insertion nut (or t-nut).
Printed on a makerbot replicator 2. Mounted via m3 12mm bolt and an insertion nut similar to this: https://www.inventables.com/technologies/pre-assembly-insertion-nuts

With inspiration from davtr's Prusa i3 MK2-X build (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1692666), The Hawk was born. For those unfamiliar with the MK2-X build, it is basically an amalgamation of Josef Prusa's i3 MK2 and the old RepRap RebeliX build. The theory is that the stronger frame of the RebeliX printer and the amazing mechanics of the MK2 can be combined to make the ultimate Prusa-style printer. That's our interpretation, anyway. Visit davtr's MK2-X page for more information. Our rendition of the printer includes fewer parts and a few design changes we found made our experience even better. Let's get to it!

Printer:

The Hawk (Prusa i3 MK2)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

20-25%

Notes:

We printed all the parts except the listed ones below at 0.3mm layers, 3-4 perimeters, 3 bottom and 4 top layers, 20-25% infill, in ABS. These settings seem to work really well for most of the parts, offering strength and efficiency of plastic used. Feel free to up the infill if you aren't using ABS or you think you might need more.
IDLER_PULLEY is printed with supports. Print the Y_IDLER_MOUNT with a higher infill percentage (30-40%).

Required Parts

For this build, you will need a few key components. The frame is made using 30X30mm aluminum extrusions, 8mm linear rods, and t-nuts are all from Misumi.
X: 360mm (3x) (GFS6-3030-360 )
Y: 320mm (2x) (GFS6-3030-320)
Z: 330mm (2x) (GFS6-3030-330)

Linear Shaft:
X: 360mm (2x) (PSFG8-360)
Y: 360mm (2x) (PSFG8-360)
Z: 325mm (2x) (PSFG8-325)

Aluminium Frame Nuts:
Pack of 100 (HNKK6-6)

title: Box or table tray with lip and cover (Customizable/parametric with OpenSCAD)

description.text:
It can be flipped to be a regular box or table tray.

The main tray.scad file is Public Domain Dedication license, but if you are interested in roundedcube.scad, I would like for you to keep me in the loop.

If you open tray.scad, there are variables that allow you to customize a lot of things about the tray. I'm new to 3D printing, and would change some things about my settings for next time. I might have gone with thicker walls and a little more tray height (that's the rim), but I opted to use less filament. So you might want to adjust that especially if you're still getting used to print settings. If you really know a lot about it, then I think you can easily successfully print this as-is. The next time I print one I'll upload a new .scad file. It turned out good and usable.

If you have customized the tray.scad file -- When you are ready to export for printing, set your $fs variable in roundedcube.scad to 0.01 to get smoother corners. It will take longer to render but it is worth it when the customization is ready.

The modules/functions in tray.scad to keep in mind are build_base() and build_top(). The latter is commented out in the file upload. So you will only see the base when you open the file. This way, you can comment one, export, print, then swap the comments and print the other part.
To add to the box's functionality, I drilled holes in the sides and stretched elastic bands through them

author: metaview

print_settings.Notes:: Quality of the mating gear surfaces is important! Adjust you print until they mesh nicely.

description.text:
Adjusting the height of the laser on the Emblaser 1 can be quite difficult. By default, the mount is a friction fit and must be forced up or down by hand. This works well for the most part, but if trying to cut through a material at the maximum thickness, fine adjustments are difficult due to gantry flex.

This design adds a rack gear to the mount, and spur gears to the laser extrusion. This allows the spur gears to be turned by hand to raise and lower the laser height very accurately. A shortened fan mount is included to suit.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D2VDYSpouYY

This design is not compatible with the standard safety cover. It depresses the micro switch to keep the laser primed as if the standard cover was in place. I will release a modified safety cover in future, although I currently don't use it.

2 x M3x12mm screws are required to attach the gear clips to the laser extrusion. If the parts are printed accurately, they will press against the extrusion enough to stop the clip from sliding, but not prevent the gear from turning.

Printer Brand:

Solidoodle

Printer:

Solidoodle 2 - Expert

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15 layer height

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Quality of the mating gear surfaces is important! Adjust you print until they mesh nicely.

Screw Threads

The threads on the fan mount and gear clips are all M3. I drilled mine out to 2.5mm to clean up the print, countersunk the head a fraction and then carefully screwed in a bolt to cut the thread.

Acetone Smoothing

For maximum strength, I recommend acetone smoothing the gantry clip. This will prevent the pressure of the gears meshing from splitting the layers apart. The smooth surface may also assist with the part sliding up and down the laser extrusion uniformly.

This thing was modeled using Onshape after using vernier calipers to measure the original parts. the document can be seen here:

https://cad.onshape.com/documents/bcb33848b02e210d76d47ae5/w/25245241d7e94cf6d298bfef/e/05b7af06328a5f0f14774ca1

If you need to make adjustments, make a copy and edit as necessary.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed this using 3D Solutech Blue 1.75mm Ultra PLA filament.  This print was the only print I had come out successful off of that roll of filament.   I did use dense supports and about 1.6mm of extra inflation distance for the support structures to help with removing the support structures cleanly, though with the size of the print, I am unsure if it was necessary.

remixed_from.author: bda
remixed_from.title: Customizable comfy spinner caps. Cap for any bearing.

title: customizable bearing cap with finger pit

description.text:
A parametric ball bearing finger cap. This is based on bda’s “Customizable comfy spinner caps. Cap for any bearing.”, but you have to put in some measures as length (in millimetre). The important ones:

  • Shaft diameter: size of the inner hole of the bearing
  • Bearing height: distance between the two flat surfaces of the bearing. The shaft of the cap will be 45 % of this and two caps will fit into the bearing.
  • Cap diameter: the diameter of the cap. This can be smaller or larger than the outer diameter of the bearing. Pick this to taste. I use 1 mm less than the bearing size. 21 mm for the 22 mm ⌀ 608 bearing.

Some more things can be set up in the customizer, and even more things in the scad file.

The caps in the images of most of my “yacs” fidget toys are this one.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 µm

Notes:

The reason i like this is that this design brings along its own falsework and bim. I had a real problem getting off the slic3r-generated falsework from the “Super Bearing Cap - 21 mm”s and ended up printing them stem up.

So, select “Falsework and brim” in the customizer and no “supports” in the slicer.

The design assumes a standard setup. When you want to use layers ≠ 200 µm or if you have a nozzle ⌀ ≠ 0.4 mm, you should change the corresponding values in the scad file and create the stl (or obj) file yourself.

Remove the falsework with a wood carving knife or similar. Trim parts of the underside hanging below the rim. Clip into your bearing. Use a file, or the customizer, OpenSCAD or your slicer to change the scale when it doesn’t fit at first because of printer tolerances.

Q: What does an engineer do when you hand em a red rubber ball and ask for its volume?
A: Look at it, and when ey’s found the model number look up the volume in eir red-rubber-ball reference table.

I liked some aspects of bda’s comfy bearing cap so much that i took it as the base for this. What i didn’t like was that you had to put in the model number of your bearing, and it worked only for an – admittedly – long list of bearings. The one i wanted wasn’t among them. So i changed this and you have to put in some length now. I also changed the way the main shape of the pin and cap is defined, check out the scad file for details.

More visible: i replaced the chamfer on the bottom and top of the cap part with a rounding (or fillet) on top. Prints much better now, at least for me.

As always, (my part of the) design history at github.

I added a third falsework ring

falsework: a temporary frame serving to support and brace a building under construction until it can stand alone.

In other word, those structures that you sometimes need when printing overhangs. My guess is that the first people that wrote a slicer just didn’t know that word, maybe even the large scale construction concept, and reinvented the wheel and named it the “circular transportation facilitation device”. Or “supports”. I try my best to use the correct word, falsework, when possible.

description.text:
One day, I saw the Edelkrone and that's cool! But it's too experience for me, so I decide to made one.
I bought the manual slider from China, it is cheaper, it is about $61.
The control box included 28byj-48 stepper motor, uln2003, DC/DC Step-Down Converter ,9V battery and Arduino nano.
The hole on the cover was used for 16mm switch.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PraKSWgHl3s&feature=youtu.be

comments.text:
Hi, i am very interested by your design.

Could you share also the Editable file . We can work together....

comments.text: I like this! Is there any detailed information on how you build this thing? Wich Pulley you used for the belt etc. ?
comments.author: Cloudsmasher

comments.text:
1.Arduino nano for the main controller.
2.LM317 as DC/DC converter, it step-down 9V battery to 5V power.
3.28byj-48+uln2003 as driver. The torque of 28byj-48 was weak, I will try to use another NEMA 17 stepper motor.
4.Bluetooth module as wireless reveiver.
5.36 tooth GT2 timing pulley+900mm long GT2 timing belt.

remixed_from.author: TheGoofy
remixed_from.title: Slew Bearing, parametric Design with Fusion 360

title: Slew Bearing Conic, with Spacers, parametric Design with Fusion 360

description.text:
This variation of my other Slew-Bearing has spacer-elements between the rolls. Rolls have a conic shape.

The Fusion 360 model has parameters for the spacer size, and the gap between roll and spacer. In particular the control over that gap helps to tune the design for a perfect distribution of the rolls across the track. The outer trace is horizontally split into two halves.

My earlier design has the problem, that it is difficult to control the gap between roll and track, and the gap between two neighbouring rolls, because it's only a single parameter. Another problem is the control over the bearing diameter, which depends on the number of rolls and their diameter.

The STL-files attached to this project is a bearing with 12 rolls (8 mm diameter at the center), and 2 mm spacers. The spacers are split in an lower and an upper part for better 3d-printability. Their shape is identical - nevertheless I've exported them separately.

Related video (tutorial with cylinder rolls): https://youtu.be/5o4Fj8OxkB8

comments.author: blole

comments.text: I wonder if it is possible to apply an herringbone gear pattern to the connical rollers and the track/rings.  If done right it seems that almost all the action would be rolling with minimal sliding and one wouldn't need spacers at all with the gear-rollers automatically staying in place.  Of course they would have to be set in place correctly at the start.  As long as the system didn't slip a cog it would seem to run smoothly, perhaps better than this setup or its ancestor.  Of course it could not be made quite so small as these can, considering how wicked-complex of a design it would be. :-)
comments.author: foxpup

comments.text: Good idea! That should be doable. The gear teeth wouldn't even need to be as high, because there is no torque. A pressure angle of 45° or higher might be even better to absorb the forces on the bearing.

description.text:
A simple filament cleaner and oiler mounted on top of your enclosure. If your spool is outside the enclosure this will integrate cleaning filament from dust before entering enclosure. You could mount an M5 pneumatic connector at bottom and attach a PTFE tube for better guide to the extruder. Only works for direct drive extruders.

This is for 1.75mm filament, but it should be fine to drill up the bottom hole for 3mm. You should drill the hole anyway for a little more play.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed everything without trouble in ABS. So bridging should be ok without support and cooling.

Drilled the hole with 2mm drill as my bottom layer is a little wider. Tapped bottom with M5 and fitted pneumatic connector and PTFE tube if you want this. Attach cleaner to Enclosure

I have a acrylic glass enclosure. I just glued the cleaner on the top of a 10mm hole for pneumatic connector to fit and have my spool located over the connector so the pull angle is straight down.

Fill the cup with foam.

Make sure it's not to tight, just enough for the filament to slide through it. Add a splash of oil if you want less friction. It might be easier to add foam after you loaded your new spool.

Original design file

I attached the solidworks part file if you want to make changes. Happy printing.

title: MOAB Water Pipe Scientific 4.5in Diameter 13.5in Tall Ice Cold

description.text:
This is as good as it gets before you spend the big bucks. Guarantied for ice cold smoke MOAB (Mother of All Bipes) will deliver. Single large circular cyclone bubbler provide a twirling of the water to enable better filtration while multiple nozzles break up the smoke into fine bubbles Moving to the mid chamber 2 versions exist, one for PLA in which the bowl is made out of plastic. I have found that if you only do one bowl ever 30 min then the plastic will not melt. DO NOT USE ABS as it will melt right away. The second version is made to accommodate a Glass Bowl 14mm (http://www.ebay.com/sch/i.html?_sacat=0&_from=R40&_nkw=Glass+Bowl+14mm&_sop=15) found on ebay for 7$ The MOAB also features a Carburetor so you do not have to remove your piece along with the Venturi effect (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venturi_effect) to constantly draw smoke in and make sure that no matter what your bowl will not fill with water or blow your bowl out even if you cough into the bong. (Tested and passed) Snap together joints are incorporated so that no matter what it will only separate when you take a screwdriver to it, keeping you from breaking your glass piece because you swung it around by the top and it separated. How to use
Fill up the bottom section with about 5 Ice cubes then water to the top
Fill the mid-section up with ice
Snap together. Be careful as this thing is serious.

Make sure your printer is calibrated
ABS
75mm feed and travel
0.2mm height
239'c nozzle
109'c bed the PLA I used GITD plastic My I7 computer took about 40min to slice the parts and each one about 14 hours to build.

comments.text:
Just got done printing this on my RXL.
Tips:Don't print in ABS. All three pieces are so big, and the print so long, that it WILL warp and crack.
Patch holes with ABS glue (if done in ABS)
As an avid solidworks user it would be sweeeeeeeeet to get some source files to pretty it up, and tweak to my tastes.
Other than that, it smokes greaaaaat.
comments.author: wubbllez

comments.text:
I'm
glad you like it :)
I did not have the cracking and warping problem when I printed
abs (the glow one is pla and the purple one is ABS)
I would suggest putting your printer in the tub in the bathroom
as that place in my experience receives the least about of airflow making ABS
prints come out better.
Also patch up cracks and holes with ABS melted in acetone; this
will be far better than glue.
ABS glue is the term I use for ABS melted in acetone. lel

remixed_from.title: Cover / 70mm Fan Mount for Geeetech GT2560

title: Cover / 40mm, 70mm Fan Mount for Geeetech GT2560
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
[Update 30.08.2017]
since the fan mount has resonated with the fan vibration and was very loud, i went back two steps. Currently i'm using:

  • GT2560_Cover_Standoff.stl (found here)
  • GT2560, 70mm Fan - MOAB (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2501348)
  • 70mm Honeycomb Fan Grill (Customized) (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2507222)

=====================

this is a remix from:
Cover / 70mm Fan Mount for Geeetech GT2560 by esurplusplus https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1810089

i like the design of the open cover!
that way, my cable management is not limited into small holes somewhere i don't need them.

i basically just converted the original (for 70mm fan) file into a cover for a 40mm fan.
(original files included and untouched)

======== Original Summary ==========

Simple cover / 70mm fan mount for a Geeetech GT2560 contoller board. Includes a standoff for the back side of the board. I secured mine by gluing in M3 threaded rods (M3 screws with the heads cut off) into the cover (long enough to go through the board/standoff/and printer frame) and M3 nuts.

title: Iron Mans War Machine 6 foot tall
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I've had several requests for War Machine and it really has just been about time to deliver. I have a dozen variations of War Machine but I believe I've compiled this to be the best. The individual pieces will need to be increased 2000% but dont quote me on that. I only processed one side so you will need to duplicate and mirror to create the oposite side pieces. Or you can do What I do and save the pieces from the larger model as you (print) go.
As always this is an untested print so dont be discouraged it you encounter a hiccup. I generally do, but thats how you learn to improve going forward, Cheers Jace

PS if you do take the time to work on or split the files further Please reupload as a remix so we can all enjoy Thanks

description.text: A simple first build, a Smartphone, tablet, remote stand for keeping your tech in place. Holds 3 and the revised holds 4 . This is my first design to print try.

Tech stand/ charging holder

My bedside table is so crowded with stuff and too much tech so to clear the deck a bit and keep it in place for charging overnight I thought this would be an easy design to start with, being new to 3d design for printing and a useful item to print. Then having printed it I thought that with a simple revision it could hold 4. The pictures are of the original, I have yet to print the revised design. I've included both versions.

title: CoreXY Chimera and Cyclops X carriage

description.text:
This is a carriage that I created for my new printer which is based on the Vulcanus 1.1 design.

It's designed so that it can easily be changed without having to dismantle most of the printer, the hotend can be removed from the carriage without dismantling it and the clamps for the belts make it very easy to adjust the tension and attach/detach them.

The carriage is made as narrow as possible to maximise the print area and I've added two mounting points, either of which can take a 3DTouch bed levelling sensor and the other can then be used to attach a cooling fan.

The carriage clips over the linear bearings and can be removed by simply unclipping it without dismantling the rest of the carriage.

With v1.1 of the design I've improved/changed a few things. The mounts for the 3DTouch sensor and cooling fan assembly are now level with the bottom of the carriage. This makes it much easier to print and gives more flexibility on the height of the sensor.

V1.2 of the design is a further refinement which improves the belt clamp strength and allows more room for wiring through the wire slot/cutout. I had a V1.1 (PLA) break after I made a gcode mistake and smashed it into the max X position whilst experimenting. V1.2 was born as a result, giving the outer belt clamp more support.

V1.2.1 of the design includes some changes to make printing easier and also experimental support for 10mm shafts using LM10UU or LM10LUU bearings.

This new design will require a spacer to be used to set the height of the sensor, I've added a customisable OpenSCAD design for a suitable spacer allowing the thickness to be adjusted.

I've changed the belt clamp orientation after having issues with the belt pulling out of the clamps when under tension. By rotating the clamp the grip on the belt is much improved. It does mean that the carriage can only be installed in one orientation.

This is still a work in progress as I am still building my printer so the design may change but for the moment it appears to function as I expected.

I've enabled the customiser so you can select a different carriage width, different spacing between bars and a different belt clamp depth to allow it to be adapted to suit other similar printer designs.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print as is so the belt clamps print as clean as possible, supports are needed.

comments.text: If you could, I’d appreciate it. As long as it gets the job done I don’t mind it being ugly at all.
comments.author: Jasonpgr

comments.text: I just started printing this up and I only now realize that there's no part cooling fan for this mount. Did you have a fan that you used on yours? It's got a great spot to mount something using the tab and two holes on the side that aren't used for the BL Touch.
comments.author: Jasonpgr

comments.text: Yes, the fan can mount on the spare tab. I have a fan design using a blower fan on my list of things to do but for the moment I'm using a simple 40mm cooling fan with a duct. I can add the .stl files for my setup to the item, it's not pretty or clever but it does the job !
comments.author: Jasonpgr

comments.text: I've added the .stl files, the bracket mounts on top of the carriage and then the duct attaches to it and can be angled/adjusted. The fan is high up so it's clear of the front bar of the printer frame. I've added a picture of my current setup, using a single nozzle at the moment as I only fit the second nozzle when I need it - saves it dragging on the print. I also have a chain link mount on top of the BL Touch, all my electrical connections use inline JST XH connectors at the carriage so I can easily swap and change.
comments.author: landie

comments.text: Is there any chance I could convince you to make one of these that will work on the Vulcanus Max? I just printed this thing off and tried to use it, but the V1.1 looks like it uses 8mm rods rather than the 10mm used on the max version so I wasn't able to make it fit my bearings/rods. I'd remix it myself, but I'm totally useless when it comes to 3d modeling or cad software of any kind, and the customizer app doesn't seem to be working. Not sure if it's just not working for me, or if it's down for everyone all together.
comments.author: Jasonpgr

comments.text: I've amended the design to add support for the larger LM10UU bearings (or single LM10LUU) and created an stl file if you want to give it a go and let me know how you get on.
comments.author: Jasonpgr

comments.text: Right on, I'll give it a shot when I get home from work tonight. I don't remember if the rod spacing is any different for the v1 or 1.1, but I think they're the X axis smooth rods are spaced 50mm on center on the max, so hopefully they're the same.
comments.author: landie

comments.text: I think they are still 50mm spacing, I downloaded the .stl for the max for an X axis end piece and double checked.
comments.author: Jasonpgr

comments.text: So the carriage fits the printer perfectly, but just my luck, when my Cyclops hotend arrived it just happened to be the new version that e3d just released. So it's slightly wider than the previous version. Luckily the screw holes still line up to mount it, but the filament holes are slightly further apart than those on the mount. I think I'll be able to file/sand it down enough to make it fit anyway though.
comments.author: landie

comments.text: Just checked on the e3d site and the centres are now 20mm instead of 18mm. I can amend the design to allow for that if needed, let me know.
comments.author: Jasonpgr

comments.text: If you wouldn't mind that would be fantastic. Probably better to have it all printed as one piece rather than dremeling out more material and weakening it needlessly
comments.author: landie

comments.text: I've added a new .stl, ChimeraPlusMount_10mm.stl that uses the spacing on the e3d web site - 20mm between centres instead of 18mm. To stop the bearing housing getting too thin I've also decreased the diameter of the holes to 9mm from 10mm as I think you only need the bigger diameter to accommodate the chinese clones that use screw on push connectors.
comments.author: Jasonpgr

comments.text: Customizer has been broken for ages, shouldn't be a problem to produce a version to take larger bearings though. I'll take a look at it.

author: journet

title: drag chain mounts for prusa i3 rework 1.5

description.text:
This is my attempt to use drag chains on a prusa i3 rework 1.5 for all axes. The most tricky part was the design of the Y-mount because I wanted that the whole printer still fits in the STUVA cabinet.
I made the parts, as you can see on the picture, but I haven't had the time to post them yet.

The prerequisite is the use of the Z-frame stiffener available on the e-motion site.
https://data.emotion-tech.com/ftp/Prusa_I3_Rework_et_Ordbot/Ressources_3D/Prusa_i3_Rework_rev1.5/Ameliorations/Renforts_tiges_filete/Illustration_renforts_Prusa_i3_rework.jpg

Extra features comming with the mounts are:

  • A guiding funnel for an easier insertion of the filament (orange part on the extruder top)
  • A cable guide on the extruder that allows to tidy up the mess a bit
  • An improved support for the X-endstop (2 adjustable screws in a slot)
  • A protection and guide for the heat-bed cables
  • A rear platform where all cables end up so they can be properly fixed and led to the RAMPS

So, if there are some people out there who are interested in those parts, let me know.
I'll need some time to clean up my files in order to post the latest versions.

NB: The stl file is only a dummy because I had to upload something.

title: Smallest R188/M4 Tri-spinner for little hands

description.text:
My nephew asked me for a fidget spinner that he could handle with his little hands, so I designed this spinner as small as I could. It is just 35mm width!! It uses small and nice R188 bearings and standard metric M4 nuts. The cap parts should be printed with support and hot-inserted in the main body. Cap parts could need some sanding and a glue drop or also hot inserting. Main body doesn't require any support as it is 45º chamferred, not filleted. Also a bit of sanding would be fine for the main body. Remember to wash it well before giving it to a kid.

BE CAREFUL !! This thing contains little parts and shouldn't be given to little kids who could disassemble and eat small parts. Not recommended for kids aged below 5.

Spinning times up to 46 secs for this little thing!!!

Enjoy.

title: Layer333 3DPrinter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
We have the pleasure of presenting you our latest model of 3d machine by layertolayer.

The Layer model is a scalable printer with a robust structure and easy to use.
It is a printer built with profiles of 20x20mm aluminum which form a #Prusa type geometry but with the improvement of a profile of reinforcement to improve the speed, print quality and ease of transport.

It has #E3D extruder of different models like v6, chimera or volcano.
Build volume 300 x 300 x 300 mm!!

It assembles an electronica totally independent of the machine to improve its useful life, maintenance and possibility of improvements.
It takes the classic but reliable #Arduino2560+Ramps1.4 system with the possibility of introducing #RaspberryPi in the same box.
The firmware is #Marlin RC8.

The quality, speed and ease of maintenance and improvement make this machine one of the most complete 3D printer on the market.

We are still working on it and as we improve it will be available to the client any of the improvements.

Designed by Roberto Brun
Maked by Avelino Suarez

All rights reserved.

title: Prusa I3 top z 8mm rod and 698zz bearing bracket 17mm spacing

description.text:
UPDATE

I apologise for not mentioning as i found out myself which i forgot that these are m4 not m3, when i got my frame cut 4 yrs ago the dxf was set at 3mm so i had to tap my frame out to m4, i also added the bottom brackets too as i had to change them to m4 as i found out after trying the m3 ones. used fusion 360 change the mesh to brep then went to patch merged as much of the triangles to make a better solid, then i sketched onto the plane

Only seen today theres another bracket the same so i've tried to mark it down as a remix, but its strange how two people come up with similar design

Printer Brand:

Duplicator 4S

Printer:

Wanhao

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

10%

Fusion 360

1st i imported stl to fusion 360 i did convert it to brep, then i created sketch outline the original bracket (prusa i3 github)extruded it the height of the part above the frame mounting holes (the part was facing downwards the biggest face flat for ref), 2nd I created a sketch on the face to remove the stock which the rod and bearing, leaving enough stock for the m4 frame hole side and the little chamfered support on the side, i was also using netfabb to make measurements as i need the centre of the 8mm hole to the centre of the hole for the bearing to measure 17mm hole to match the x parts that fit the leadscrew as they have 17mm spacing , i created a rim around the bearing to fit the 698 bearing, i kept that size as the leadscrew bearings for the x are the same.

author: _van_

print_settings.Notes:: Most of the pieces should be arranged to print with the interior glue side down to keep the most detail possible in the model.
print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
This is a full scale, printable version of the original Thompson. It includes both the classic drum magazine, the vertical foregrip, and all of the engraved text of the original firearm. The only difference is the original ladder style rear sight has been replaced with the more popular fixed sight.

While the finished model is very sturdy overall, there is one weak spot: the connection of the foregrip to the barrel. This is the same weakness that resulted in the grip being replaced with the standard barrel foregrip, so it's at least historically accurate.

The model has no moving parts, and is fairly easy to assemble, even without internal guide rods. It does take almost an entire 1kg roll of PLA to print, and better than 80 hours of print time.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20

Notes:

Rafts are encouraged, as even with the large surface area there was some lifting on the sides. However, it's not always possible. The upper receiver/drum pieces took my full print area, but it did help the smaller pieces print flatter.

Most of the pieces should be arranged to print with the interior glue side down to keep the most detail possible in the model.

Sanding

Almost all of the pieces had to be sanded a bit to glue well. This was mostly because I printed with rafts to keep the interior faces super flat. I also had some issues getting the trigger to line up perfectly, so I rolled up some sandpaper and filed down the ridge.

Gluing

The model is designed to be printed in large pieces and glued together. Most of it went together pretty well, but I did run into issues with the upper receiver/drum pieces lining up properly. If someone wanted to model in some guide rods, that would probably help. I might give it a shot if I were to print another one.

The barrel is the easiest to put together, and I didn't end up gluing down the compensator. It fits in pretty tight, and leaving it unglued allows for adjusting the sight alignment post-assembly.

The Foregrip

As mentioned, the foregrip is really the weak point of the whole design. It holds to the main body very well, but where it connects to the barrel, not so much. I think the original (being made of metal) fared better, but even that was replaced with something sturdier.

Care must be taken when gluing the grip on to make sure the little U support lines up with one of the barrel fins. I then glued the support to the fin, but it has come apart a few times if it falls over or something.

The Dream

Ever since I watched the black and white gangster movies as a kid, I wanted a thompson. It was the first thing I thought of when I got my printer, and every thing I printed, failed, got better at, and practiced was in preparation for this. Once it was finished, I practically slept with it for days. The only down side is I can't take it into work to show off.

The Design

I combed Thingiverse for weeks looking for a good model. While I found some great guns to try out, I could never find a really good Thompson. I ended up over at grabcad.com, and found a couple of models that would work.

The main gun: https://grabcad.com/library/thompson-1928a1-model-1
The foregrip: https://grabcad.com/library/thompson-1928-no-stock

The detail and scale were great, but they were obviously not printable. I took the models, combined them, and then spent a couple of weeks modeling and repairing to get them to be one solid shell.

tools3d.azurewebsites.net really saved my bacon on this, and I don't think I would have been able to complete my repairs without it.

I then broke up the model, knowing that I only had an 8in by 8in area to print in, but wanting the finished piece to be as sturdy as possible.

Take Aways

There are still some issues with the model. Because of how it was designed, the drum was VERY hard to convert. It ended up alright, but not perfect.

I also wish I'd taken the time to model slots and guide rods into the main body for assembly, and I will before I print another one.

I'd also like to print one, sand it down, and paint it for a full movie prop. I probably will one day, but given how long this took to print, and how much PLA it took up, I'll probably just relax and enjoy the one I have for a while.

print_settings.Notes:: I have had great success printing these parts with Hatchbox TPU.  I suspect they will work fine if printed with any TPU with a Shore 95A Hardness.
print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
If printed with TPU, these rubber inserts are perfect replacement parts for the 1-1/8 and 1 oz. MEC Charge Bars. Also, there is a rubber insert for the Mec Multi-Scale Universal Charge Bar.

Added Fusion 360 file.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

In trying to match the softness of the original MEC part, I have found that 10% infill with Wall, Top, and Bottom Thicknesses set to 0.52mm works pretty good. You might have to play a little with your settings to get the right amount of softness/hardness. 100% Infill did not have enough 'give' to prevent binding on the down stroke when reloading.

I have had great success printing these parts with Hatchbox TPU. I suspect they will work fine if printed with any TPU with a Shore 95A Hardness.

Design

I designed this part using Fusion 360. I would offer the other sized Charge Bar rubber inserts, but I only use the 1-1/8 and 1 oz. sizes in my shotshell reloading. Therefore, I didn't have access to the other sizes to model.

These latest versions (I removed the old versions) are better fitted to the height of the charge bar. My first versions, although designed for 1/4-inch height, would always print a little proud of the insert cavity. These print and fit perfectly!

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/7mXmjpBlFvx

After this, Price for a Quartz Trigger Movement With Westminster Chime and Buy one from a Clock Shop, Also get a Second Hand.

Place one AA Battery for the motor and Two AA Batteries for the Chimes. Then, place the batteries in and push the Red button to set the chimes.

title: Tablet Mount >10in adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Tablet mounts like the Monoprice #9585 (http://www.monoprice.com/Product?c_id=109&cp_id=10828&cs_id=1082814&p_id=9585&seq=1&format=2) claim to be a universal mount for tablets up to 10in. That being said tablets like the Asus Transformer are slightly too large. This is a replacement for the lower holding brackets, extending them slightly, which accommodates the larger tablets without issue.
Print this out, unscrew the two lower brackets and replace these using the existing mounting hardware.

description.text:
I had quite a bit of wobbling on Wanhao Duplicator i3. The problem was the connections of X-axis roads, which I solved by printing additional supports as can be seen in the pictures.

Please notice that supports on the left are longer than on the right.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Notes:

Perimeters: 3

I was looking for a way to use the Dremel 225 Flexible Shaft while not having my Dremel 4000 buzzing all over the place. The solution was simple: hang the 4000 from its hook and secure the 225 by clicking it in a tight clip. Works with no problem at 35.000 rpm :).

The top holder is a remake from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1280556, just adapted it to have the same style.

remixed_from.author: piercet
remixed_from.title: LED Strip Mount Angle Brackets and Join Plate for use with upper Gantry Printers like the AO-10x, Mendelmax or the TAZ

title: Endcaps and wire guides for LED light bars

description.text:
This is a set of right and left endcaps for the LED light strip bars, They go with the AO-10x / Mendelmax bracket set that I designed, but may also fit Flurin's brackets potentially.   
Uploaded a 5mm wider mount and 8mm longer endcap module as well, for additional wire room. You can mix and match those components as needed

Print out 2 of the Endcap_b parts, and one set of the Right and left side pieces. Drill a hole in the end of one of the endcap B parts, and fit that over the end of your LED strip that has your connection wires. Now fit that part into one of the right or left side pieces, and thread the wire back towards your 20mm extrusion in the provided channel. I may also upload a thicker version of this for larger diameter wires here in a bit. You do not need to drill out the other side, as it is mainly decorative.

author: piercet

title: Samsung S7 car loader and holder

description.text:
To make this thing you need these parts:
Bumper like the shown one (spigen)
QI Loader like the shown one (vinsic)
Car holder like the shown one (Logilink)
In my car it works fine.
